text: We'll now look at Chapter 9, which is on linear dynamical systems. Uh, it's an application area, um, actually,
it's used in- in many- many- many fields, so it's a very good thing to know about. And at its essence,
it really only uses nothing but matrix-vector multiplication, which is something we know about now. Okay, so let's take a look.
So we'll start with what is a linear dynamical system, and then we're gonna look at two practical examples.
Now, the examples I'm gonna show you are going to be a- a bit simplified, of course, uh, but it'll give you a rough idea of how uh,
real ones actually are done. Okay. So, uh, let's start with the setting.
So I have a sequence of n-vectors and we're gonna call those x_1, x_2, x_3, and so on.
Now, here the index denotes something like the time or the period.
Could be, you know, that maybe, something about they- they could measure time at a fixed interval like daily,
hourly, um, but it doesn't have to be, it could be, for example, trading days in finance.
Trading days in finance, you know, doesn't count weekends and market holidays. So, that would be- that's what the- the basically t,
the- the subscript t, uh, here, uh, if you have x sub t-,
a t is just a mnemonic supposed to hint at time, that's the idea, okay. And these are n-vectors.
Notice the notation is a bit ambiguous, right? That, in this case, the subscript doesn't mean the tth index of the vector x.
It means x sub t, which is the tth vector in a sequence of vectors.
Okay, if you wanna talk about the third entry of x_7, you write it like this,
and the interpretation is that is the third component of x_7,
which is, uh, the state at time t equals 7. Okay? So that's where x_t is gonna be called the state.
Um, x is a traditional symbol for the state, but there's lots of others that are used.
And the sequence is called a state trajectory. A trajectory just tells you how something evolves across time,
and so that's what this is, uh- that's what this is called. It's a state trajectory. Um, now, just to give you a rough idea of how this works,
if t is the current time, say it's today or something like that, then x_t, we refer to that as the current state.
It's a state at the time right now. X sub t minus 1, that's the previous state. So for example, if this is daily,
x sub t minus 1 is the state yesterday, x_t plus 1, that's the next state.
So if this were daily, x_t plus 1 would be the state tomorrow.
Okay? And x_t, what does it represent? It can represent many- many- many things, but for example, we'll look at it for a couple of examples.
But we'll look at one where it represents the age-, the age distribution in a population.
And that means basically the entries tell you how many people there are in some population of a certain age and x_t gives you the age distribution.
Very common one is in economics where x_t, the entries of x_t give you the economic output in n sectors of the economy, right?
So the different entries of x tell you how different sectors did in that period.
And it's very common for mechanical systems to- to describe this when there,
the entries of x are typically positions or displacements, um, and also uh, they could-,
they will typically include also velocities and momentum. Okay? So, but the idea right now is- is just a vector sequence.
Okay. Now, linear dynamics uh, is this.
It's a very special form. It says x_t plus 1 is a_t, x_t.
And that simply says that the next state is obtained from the current state by simply multiplying by a matrix.
Okay? Another's matrices can vary with time. That's what this sub t is here.
And a sub t, that's an n-by-n matrix, it's usually called the dynamics matrix or the update matrix.
Dynamics is pretty- it is a very common term to refer to this. Right? And we can interpret,
uh, now there's a lot of, uh, a lot of indices flying around here, so you have to be very- very careful.
Um, so for example, a_t sub i_j, so t,
it denotes the time, or the period. Oh, another name for time or period is epoch.
So, I don't know. It's an old- old name for it, but okay. Then i_j are of course the entries in the,
in the n-by-n matrix a sub t. And so the i_j entry tells you how much the jth,
uh, input, uh, to the matrix vector multiplication affects the ith output.
So, for example here, if you have x_t, that's the state at time t or epoch t,
it's the jth component, then you multiply these two together and you get the contribution to the ith component of tomorrow's or,
well, that's if it's daily, but the next state component i, that comes from the current state component j.
Okay? So that's the- uh, that's the interpretation. This is quite tricky. There are a lot of indices here and you really got to be- got to sit down
and go real slow and try to understand what all these things uh, mean. Okay. Now, in many- many cases,
a does not depend on time. And so it is- it is what people would say, it's either- it's constant or you would say that it is time-invariant.
And then you would refer to this if you- if it looks like this, x_t plus 1 equals to simply ax_t,
we say that- we would- we would say that this is a linear time-invariant, uh, dynamical system.
Okay? So that's something you'll hear. And sometimes you'll hear the phrase LTI for linear time-invariant dynamical system.
Okay. Now, one thing to say right now is, of course many things are not-
many dynamical systems do not evolve according to these equations. But it turns out a lot of them do either pretty approx- pretty well,
or-, or at least approximately. And one- one thing to notice immediately is that you can interpret this as a recursion.
And what that says, for example, is if I knew the current state, I could simply multiply by at,
get x_t plus 1. I multiply that by at plus-, at plus 1 and I get x_t plus 2, and so on.
And so these are just iterated matrix-vector multiplications. And in fact, that's called simulating the evolution of the state.
If you said that anyone would understand what you're talking about. So-, and that's very cool.
You could do things like say, please simulate the system forward 10 time periods, right?
Or, uh, please- please tell me, uh, what this mechanical system is going to be doing in
the next one second when I'm- when I've sampled at a rate of, let's say, uh, 50 times a second, right?
So I would- I would propagate forward 50 time steps to see what- what- what configuration it will be and what the state will be.
So-, so you can actually, uh, basically simulate, uh, a- a linear dynamical system.
Now there are a lot of variations, uh, a very, very common one, uh, looks like this.
This is the usual update is the a_t plus- that- that's- that's the contribution to the next state from the current state.
But then people put on someth- another term which is B_t, u_t, and then even c_t.
That's less common, but it does happen. Now here, u_t is an m vector,
uh, u is in fact the traditional symbol. And it's supposed to be an input. So u_t is an input, uh,
to the dynamical system, and c_t is an offset, right? So for, I'll give you an example,
is aircraft dynamics as described by this actually with c_t equal to 0.
U_t is a vector that tells you about the various things you can do to control the airplane.
For example, what are the angles of the control surfaces like the rudder, airle- ailerons, elevator, things like that,
right? So that's what that is. Or one might be the engine thrust. So it would- it would tell you things like if
you were to increase your thrust, what would happen. If you were to turn your rudder, you know, left two degrees,
like what would happen? Okay. And that's- that- that has a model like that. In fact, that's actually- that's a very common model
actually for all of what's called modern control, and for that matter navigation,
that there's entire courses on nothing but this linear dynamic system.
Right? So at Stanford we have one. That's EE263. Okay. So B is referred to as the input matrix here,
U is the input. Um, usually, in those applications, U is something we might have control over
and so the natural questions you'd ask would be, what would be a good sequence of inputs to apply to my system?

Okay. Um, another, uh, common version is, uh,
is something like this. This is a- the so-called K-Markov model. Um, and what it says is that the next state,
that's x_t plus 1 is a, uh, actually, it's a sum of contributions from the current state,
the previous state, the previous previous state and so on, and this goes back, uh, K steps.
Um, and in fact, sometimes people call that the memory of the system because basically it says that the next state depends not just on the current state,
that would be a linear dy- a simple, basic linear dynamical system. But in fact, it depends on the current state,
the previous state, and maybe, you know, going back or something like that. So that's called, um- that's sometimes called the memory of such a system,
um, and this is called K-Markov, uh, model. Um, it's also called in other contexts like in statistics,
autoregressive or vector autoregressive, so VAR model. It's got lots of names.
Um, okay. So that's a- that's an autoregressive model, and when capital K is 1, that's the memory.

just one quick story about what state means. Um, so the- there's- there is a definition of state.
And what state means is it's a nu- it's a summary of what you need to know about the past to be able to predict the future.
That's what the state is. And if we go back here, you'll see that that's exactly what this does.
Um, so for example, if I said, you know, "Please- please show me the next three states like x_t plus 1,
x_t plus 2, x_ t plus 3." All you have to know is x_t. You don't have to know what x_t minus 1 was, x_t minus 2.
It is no one's business how the system got into the state x_t, because once you have x_t, you multiply it by A_t,
and you get x_ t plus 1. Then you multiply that by A_t plus 1 and you get x_t plus 2 and so on.
So the point is that x_t really is a bonafide summary of the past,
uh, sufficient to allow you to predict the future, right? So some people would call it a sufficient statistic or something like that.

people wouldn't call x_t the state here. The state is actually- it's the collection, you know, x_t, x_t minus 1,
